persona.name: Jordan Kim-Rodriguez

occupation.title: Senior IT Systems Consultant — Municipal & Sustainability Projects
occupation.description: Jordan works as a senior consultant focused on integrating IT systems for public-sector clients (city departments, transit agencies, local utilities). Responsibilities include scoping projects, designing system architecture, liaising with city stakeholders and community groups, supervising junior consultants, and ensuring projects meet both technical and policy goals (especially environmental targets). Skilled at translating between non-technical decision-makers and engineering teams. Regular tasks: requirements workshops, writing RFP responses, running pilot deployments of sensors or software, coordinating data privacy reviews, and producing accessible public-facing dashboards. Known for pragmatic troubleshooting on-site and writing clear technical documentation. Uses experience to push for sustainable procurement choices and lifecycle cost analyses when possible. Comfortable running vendor evaluations, mentoring 2–3 junior staff, and occasionally delivering public presentations at local conferences.

persona.education: Bachelor's degree in Computer Science, Oregon State University. Completed a senior project on low-power data aggregation for environmental sensors. Took electives in environmental policy and urban planning. Participated in a semester-long internship at a municipal IT department focused on mapping and open data.
long_term_goals: To build or join a company division that creates technology products explicitly aimed at reducing municipal carbon footprints (smart transit, energy analytics).
To buy and renovate an older house into a small, energy-efficient co-housing project that supports extended family and friends.
To develop deeper roots in their local community by serving on a neighborhood association and mentoring youth from underrepresented backgrounds in STEM.
To achieve financial stability sufficient for occasional long-term travel and the ability to take sabbaticals for community projects.
To age with good physical and mental health, maintaining strong friendships and chosen-family relationships, while preserving autonomy and mobility.

style.general: Conversational, deliberate, and approachable. Speaks in a measured Pacific Northwest-American cadence with occasional uptalk when uncertain. Uses gender-neutral pronouns (they/them) and corrects pronoun use gently but firmly when needed.
style.vocabulary_and_tone: Mixes plain language with technical terms when necessary. Avoids jargon in public meetings; flips to more technical vocabulary with engineers. Has a dry, slightly wry sense of humor and often uses analogies involving bicycles, gardens, or transit.
style.mannerisms: Tends to fidget with a pen or reusable straw while thinking. Nods to show active listening. Tilts head slightly before answering complex questions. Uses hands moderately when explaining technical flows. Maintains eye contact but is quick to smile to signal warmth.
style.dress: Casual-smart: dark jeans, a modest blazer or a windbreaker, and functional shoes (e.g., waterproof sneakers). Often wears a lapel pin or enamel badge that signals support for a local cause. Carries a well-used messenger bag with a laptop, notebook, and a stainless-steel water bottle.
style.communication_preferences: Prefers asynchronous written updates (email or project management tool) for tracking decisions, but values in-person or video discussions for brainstorming and conflict resolution. Appreciates agendas and timeboxing in meetings.

traits: Pragmatic idealist — wants big changes but prioritizes feasible steps.
Conscientious and deadline-oriented, rarely misses deliverables.
Socially warm with close friends, moderately reserved with new acquaintances.
Curious about systems, enjoys tracing root causes rather than treating symptoms.
Emotionally steady under pressure but experiences intermittent low-level anxiety.
Values fairness and inclusivity; quick to notice when someone is left out.
Independent — comfortable making decisions alone but seeks counsel when stakes are high.
Detail-minded when it matters, flexible about non-essential details.
Resourceful — enjoys DIY repairs and finding cheaper sustainable alternatives.
Witty and sardonic at times; uses humor to defuse tension.
Persistent — follows through on long projects even when enthusiasm wanes.
Reflective — schedules regular self-check-ins and journaling time.

explanations.openness: Enjoys new ideas (tech, policy, culture) and is receptive to creative problem-solving but also filters novelty through a practical lens.
explanations.conscientiousness: Highly organized for work; keeps lists and standards. Sometimes struggles to relax but works to maintain boundaries.
explanations.extraversion: Not overtly outgoing; recharges alone but can be engaging and animated in small group settings.
explanations.agreeableness: Generally cooperative and empathetic; will push back if principles or data are on the line.
explanations.neuroticism: Manages stress with routines, therapy, and exercise; tends not to catastrophize but has moments of worry about long-term issues (finances, climate).

interests: Urban cycling and bike-commuting: enjoys mapping safer routes and advocates for protected lanes.
Community gardening and native-plant landscaping.
Open data and civic tech — contributing to local open-source city-tools.
Reading: longform journalism, environmental policy papers, and well-reviewed speculative fiction.
Podcasts about infrastructure, design, and policy (e.g., CityLab, Planet Money).
Independent coffee shops more than chains, often a place to do deep work.
Cooking: building vegetable-centric meals from seasonal farmers' market finds.
Home DIY: tiling, basic plumbing, weatherization projects.
Bouldering occasionally on weekends as cross-training.
Photography focused on urban textures and public spaces.
Travel oriented toward trains and slow travel rather than flights when possible.
Gardening: composting, seed swapping, and saving heirloom seeds.
Board games (strategy-heavy) with a close friend group.
Volunteering for neighborhood cleanup days and transit rider advocacy.
Minimal social media engagement: prefers newsletters and curated RSS feeds.
Sustainability meetups and occasional public comment at city hearings.
Attending local theatre and small music venues.
Collecting maps and transit ephemera.
Learning Spanish conversationally (family heritage) and basic Korean phrases from partner family visits.
Participating in co-op tool libraries and maker-space workshops.
Following tech trends that intersect with public good (edge computing for sensors).
Savoring slow weekend mornings with a newspaper or long-form article.
Prefers experiences (workshops, classes) over new consumer goods.
Practicing mindfulness via short daily breathing exercises.
Documenting projects and publishing how-to guides for community benefit.
likes: Favorite coffee order: pour-over Ethiopian or single-origin drip, oat milk on the side.
Ambiance: quiet indie cafes with good natural light, plants, and outlets.
Streaming: PBS, local independent film festivals online, and curated documentary series; uses both broadcast and streaming.
Music: acoustic indie, folktronica, and instrumental jazz playlists for focused work.
Snacks: marcona almonds, sliced apples with almond butter, and savory seaweed snacks.
Books: long investigative nonfiction, novels with strong sense of place, and books on urban design.
Travel accommodations: small rentals in walkable neighborhoods, close to transit.
Clothing: functional layers, recycled-fabric outerwear, and thrifted vintage pieces.
Tools: a small but well-organized tool chest, good-quality drill, and cordless screwdriver.
Home tech: smart thermostat that respects privacy and local server for home automation.
Food markets: weekly farmer’s market, local purveyors, artisanal bread.
Coffee shops to work from when needed: two local favorites known for reliable wifi and supportive staff etiquette.
Productivity tools: uses an offline notebook for weekly planning plus a cloud-based task manager.
Events: neighborhood potlucks, transit town halls, and low-key tech meetups.
Gifts: prefers gifting experiences or contributing to crowdfunding for causes friends care about.
Sustainable habits: carrying a reusable fork set, cloth produce bags, and a coffee tumbler.
Movies: prefers character-driven independent films and documentaries over mainstream blockbusters.
Restaurants: farm-to-table places that list sourcing and have vegetarian-forward menus.
Fitness: short HIIT sessions mixed with longer weekend bike rides.
Design: favors functional design, secondhand finds, and craft over mass-produced home decor.
Coffee shop behavior: orders once, tips well, and moves to allow turnover if busy.
Phone use: manual Do Not Disturb at night, keeps notifications selective.
Socializing: deep conversations with a small circle rather than large parties.
Learning: enjoys short online courses on civic tech, data visualization, and sustainable building practices.
Seasonal rituals: winter hibernation reading lists, summer bike-camping trips.
dislikes: Heavy social-media-driven argument threads and performative outrage.
Consumerist holiday culture; prefers meaningful giving.
Corporate greenwashing and superficial sustainability claims.
Long, bureaucratic city hearings with little transparency.
Overly noisy open-plan offices where focus is hard to maintain.
Flimsy, single-use packaging and plastic waste.
Pseudoscience and poorly sourced statistics used to argue policy.
Aggressive drivers and poorly designed intersections.
Poorly maintained public transit and service cuts.
High-pressured sales tactics or forced networking.
Being rushed through technical explanations without context.
Any product or policy that ignores equity impacts.

daily: One longform article or essay (The Atlantic, local investigative outlets).
A 30–60 minute podcast episode a few times a week.
Short bursts of email and project-tool updates during workday.
Limited social media checks (Twitter/X mainly for local transit updates, but not heavily engaged).
preferred_sources: Local public radio and investigative local papers.
Specialized newsletters on urbanism and climate policy.
Technical blogs and GitHub repositories for project-level reference.
Documentary streaming services or festival archives.

beliefs: Climate change is an urgent crisis that requires both municipal action and personal lifestyle shifts.
Public transit investment yields social and economic returns beyond simple ridership numbers.
Local government decisions matter — attending meetings and public comment can influence outcomes.
Technology should support public good; data collection must come with strong privacy protections.
Evidence-based policy making is essential; decisions should be driven by robust analysis and transparent metrics.
Economic costs of sustainability measures should be weighed against long-term community resilience.
Housing should be more accessible and diverse to prevent displacement and support mixed-income neighborhoods.
Single people without children are legitimate adults with valid life choices; family structures are varied and deserving of respect.
Healthcare access should be universal or at least broadly guaranteed; preventive care reduces long-term costs.
Education access and mentorship are critical for creating inclusive tech pathways.
Gentrification needs careful policy responses — community land trusts and inclusionary zoning are useful tools.
Civic engagement is a responsibility; voting, volunteering, and attending hearings are important.
Data transparency in government increases accountability and public trust.
Cities should prioritize safe infrastructure for walking and cycling over free-flow car lanes in dense areas.
Renewable energy must be scaled alongside improved energy efficiency in buildings.
Local procurement policies can shift markets toward sustainable suppliers if cities have the will.
Workers deserve fair wages and benefits; consulting work should not be used to permanently outsource core public functions.
Community-led design processes produce more equitable and lasting outcomes than top-down mandates.
Privacy is a human right; prefer local-first or edge computing for sensitive data rather than cloud vendors when possible.
Red flag laws and closing the gun show loophole are common-sense measures that can reduce immediate threats and are compatible with due process.
Democracy in the U.S. is under strain — misinformation, disenfranchisement, and eroding norms are real concerns.
Independent political affiliation allows pragmatic coalition building across parties on specific issues like infrastructure and environment.
Political compromise is valuable but should not normalize bad faith actions or corruption.
Small individual actions (composting, transit use) help but systemic change is required to address climate at scale.
Government investment in resilient infrastructure is effective fiscal policy over the long term.
High-income households should bear more of the tax burden to fund public goods.
Science and peer review are reliable methods for establishing consensus; skepticism is healthy but should be evidence-based.
Affordable, quality childcare and family supports make societies more equitable, even for those who choose not to have children themselves.
Mental health services should be integrated into primary care and covered by insurance with parity.
Immigration enriches communities; policies should balance security with humanity.
Corporations should be regulated to prevent monopolistic practices and protect consumers and workers.
Public spaces (parks, plazas) are essential to community well-being and should be equitably distributed.
Art and cultural funding in cities improves quality of life and economic vitality.
Practical incrementalism is an effective political strategy for achieving broad buy-in on difficult reforms.
Transparency in campaign finance is necessary to reduce undue influence in policy.
Local businesses often provide irreplaceable community benefits and deserve supportive policies.
Community resilience planning must center vulnerable populations (elderly, disabled, low-income).
Technology solutionism can be seductive but often requires parallel governance and community processes.
Personal consumption choices matter but are insufficient without regulatory and infrastructural changes.
skills: Full-stack web development fundamentals (JavaScript, Node.js, basic React) — used for prototype dashboards.
Familiar with cloud services (AWS/GCP) for hosting small civic deployments, and experience with setting up privacy-respecting configurations.
Data visualization skills (D3, Tableau) for creating public-facing dashboards.
Project scoping and requirements gathering for municipal clients; adept at running stakeholder workshops.
Technical writing and documentation — writes clear runbooks and public-oriented FAQs.
Basic systems administration and Linux comfort for small servers and edge devices.
Sensor integration experience (IoT): calibrating, logging, and troubleshooting environmental sensors.
Budgeting and cost estimation for multi-year municipal projects.
Bilingual conversational Spanish and basic Korean phrases for family interactions and some community outreach.
Mentoring and on-boarding junior staff; giving constructive feedback and pair-programming.
Public speaking and presentation design for community meetings and conferences.
Conflict mediation skills in stakeholder settings; able to surface competing values and design compromises.
Basic carpentry, tiling, and home maintenance skills for DIY projects.
Cycling repair and maintenance (fixing flats, adjusting brakes) used for commuting and workshops.
Comfort with accessibility best-practices for web interfaces (WCAG basics).

general: Prefers written over verbal commitments for clarity; follows up meeting notes with an email summary.
Uses reusable containers and avoids single-use plastics consistently.
Often volunteers an hour a week to community projects or mentorship.
Brings snacks to long meetings to keep energy up and to encourage informal conversation.
Checks public transit app every morning and plans routes in advance with backups.
Keeps a physical weekly planner with three must-do tasks and one stretch goal.
Sends thoughtful birthday messages and small, considered gifts to close friends rather than large gatherings.
Is direct but kind in feedback; prioritizes framing feedback with observable examples and suggested solutions.
Works in sprints: 90–120 minute blocks with Pomodoro-like breaks for concentrated tasks.
Accepts failure as feedback; documents mistakes as 'lessons learned' to share with the team.

morning: Starts with a 10-minute breathing or stretching routine.
Prepares a simple breakfast (oatmeal or eggs) and a pour-over coffee.
Skims local news headlines and project notifications while making breakfast.
Loads a small toolkit and laptop into messenger bag, checks bike tires, and cycles to the transit hub or cycles the full commute when weather is good.
workday: Arrives at co-working office or client site by 9 AM (flex schedule 8–10).
Begins with a short standup (team) and then a focused work block for high-priority tasks.
Holds one or two stakeholder meetings midmorning; spends afternoons on documentation and pilot deployments.
Takes a 30–45 minute lunch, often stepping outside or meeting a colleague in a cafe.
Wraps the day with a short triage of emails and a prioritized list for tomorrow.
evening: Returns home, prepares a vegetable-forward meal, and spends time with friends or chosen-family for dinner several nights a week.
Does light home chores (composting, watering plants) and then 30–45 minutes of personal project time (writing, learning, or repair work).
Reads for 30–60 minutes before bed; keeps a strict phone-off policy during sleep hours.
Often journals for 10 minutes reflecting on the day and gratitude items.
weekend: Longer bike rides or a short camping trip during good weather.
Dedicated time for deeper DIY projects — insulating a window, setting up a rain garden, or mending clothing.
Hosts or attends a small dinner with friends; shares food and ideas.
Volunteers at a community garden or attends a city council subcommittee occasionally.

health.physical: Generally good. Active bicycle commuter and does moderate strength and climbing activities. Has seasonal allergies (pollen) and occasional exercise-related knee soreness. Slight lactose sensitivity (tolerates small amounts). No major chronic illnesses.
health.mental: Manages mild generalized anxiety with therapy (biweekly cognitive-behavioral approaches) and meditation. Has had brief periods of insomnia under acute stress but no history of major depressive episodes. Open to medication if recommended but currently manages with lifestyle, therapy, and sleep hygiene.
health.medical_history: No surgeries besides an appendectomy in late teens. Up-to-date on vaccinations. Routine annual physical and dental checkups. Takes vitamin D in winter.
health.health_behaviors: Regular health check-ins, uses a smartwatch to monitor sleep/activity but keeps raw data private. Eats vegetarian-forward diet with occasional fish. Does not smoke and drinks alcohol socially (1–2 drinks on weekends).

entries: Mother (Luz Rodriguez, mid-60s): lives two hours away; retired elementary school teacher; warm, calls weekly; first-generation immigrant from Mexico.
Father (Sung Kim, early 70s): lives in another state; semi-retired electronics technician; visits for holidays; taught Jordan basic handyman skills and Korean phrases.
Younger sibling (Mariana, 32): lives in same metropolitan area; works in community organizing; close emotionally and shares gardening projects.
A few older cousins and an extended Latino/Asian extended family that gather for major holidays; Jordan attends selectively and maintains boundary-friendly participation.

Single — not currently seeing anyone seriously. Recent long-term relationship ended two years ago amicably. Prefers slow, intentional dating and values partners who respect sustainability and civic engagement.
Has dated people across gender identities and values compatibility over labels.
Close circle of 6–8 friends from college, work, and neighborhood; weekly dinner or game nights monthly.
Mentor (Asha): a former manager who now runs a small civic-tech nonprofit; meets quarterly for career advice.
Two colleagues who are close friends and sometimes go on weekend excursions together.
Direct reports: mentors 2 junior consultants and does performance reviews twice a year.
Local network of municipal staff, vendors, and nonprofit partners for cross-sector projects.
Member of a regional professional association for municipal IT and civic tech.
Has no children; lives with a well-behaved older rescue cat named Mochi (indoor cat), who is a comforting presence for Jordan.

other_facts: Grew up in a mid-sized West Coast city in a bilingual household, exposed early to both Spanish and Korean at home.
The hyphenated last name comes from a decision to honor both parents' heritages; Jordan is proud of the mixed cultural background and celebrates both sets of traditions.
Chose Oregon State University for affordability and strong local internship pipelines.
Worked part-time in a bike shop during college, learning mechanical skills and community-building through local cycling culture.
Still has a well-worn map from a 2013 cross-country Amtrak trip that they consult nostalgically.
Maintains a 'tool library' membership and has taught two weekend community workshops on basic home weatherization.
Has a small scar on the left forearm from a kitchen accident while learning to make sourdough bread.
Once pitched a civic-tech pilot to a city transit agency that later adopted a modified version after two years of advocacy.
Keeps a small collection of transit tokens, vintage schedules, and a framed map of the city's 1970 bus routes in their living room.
Has moderate student loan debt but has built a disciplined repayment plan and an emergency fund; values financial stability.
Is genealogically curious and has begun a part-time project documenting family stories and recipes from both sides of the family.
Has a modest tattoo behind the right ear of a stylized compass rose that symbolizes 'finding direction.'
Volunteered at a youth coding camp in college and finds mentoring young people one of the most rewarding activities.
Has a recurring dream of owning a small workshop with space for community classes and a rooftop garden.
Enjoys documenting renovation projects with a blog-like diary to help neighbors replicate low-cost efficiency upgrades.
Was once temporarily on the local public radio board as a community representative for two years.
Dislikes big weddings and prefers small, intentional gatherings; did not have a big graduation party and instead took a road trip with close friends.
Has a standing tradition of making pozole for family New Year gatherings, blending Korean and Mexican flavors in secret family recipes.
Saves and reuses jars for canning and composting; traded jars with neighbors in a seed-and-jar swap.
Participated in a neighborhood effort to convert an empty lot into a pocket park; still visits to see how the plantings matured.
Loves the tactile feel of a paper notebook and keeps one for project notes and personal reflections.
Has moderate fear of deep water (doesn't like to swim in the ocean beyond wading) stemming from a childhood near a cold, rocky shoreline.
Is proud of a small published piece on data ethics in a regional planning journal from a conference presentation in 2019.
Experiences seasonal affective dips in late winter and has an established routine (light therapy, vitamin D, exercise) to manage mood.
Has organized a neighborhood tool-sharing registry that reduced duplicative purchases and built neighbor relationships.
Once helped restore a community center's heating system temporarily during a cold snap by coordinating volunteers and local tradespeople.
Has an emergency contact list and family grab-bag in their home; participates in neighborhood emergency-preparedness meetings.
Enjoys making playlists for friends as small personal gifts tailored to moods and memories.
Has volunteered in Spanish-language voter-registration drives to improve local turnout among underrepresented communities.
Keeps a modest side fund for supporting friends in crisis (rent help, short-term loans) and prefers direct mutual aid over donating to large charities for local issues.
Has a pragmatic bucket list: visit national parks by train, learn advanced woodworking, and co-author a how-to guide on municipal sensor deployments.
Took a sabbatical-like leave for six weeks to help a coastal community map flood-prone areas after an extreme-weather event.
Uses a small solar charger for devices when camping and advocates for low-energy tech choices in deployments.
Has occasionally experienced gatekeeping in male-dominated contractor spaces and now makes a point to support women and non-binary tradespeople in hiring decisions.
Treasures a letter of recommendation from a college professor who noted Jordan's combination of technical skill and civic passion.
Once received a minor award from a local sustainability nonprofit for volunteering energy-efficiency workshops.
Keeps an 'accomplishments' folder of small wins (successful pilots, published guides, saved client budget) to counter imposter feelings on tough days.
Has a secret weakness for a specific donut shop across town and will make a detour for a maple-bacon yeast donut as a personal indulgence.
Is learning to play uke (ukulele) and uses music as a way to connect with friends and decompress.
